This description of overall social processes should not be confused with ‘individualism’, which concerns a specific notion of, or ideology about, the role of the individual in society.

The ‘Global Justice Movement’ refers to the movement associated with the 1999 mass demonstrations against the World Trade Organization in Seattle, the summit meeting demonstration during the following years, and the large alternative conferences that have been labeled social forums (in particular the World Social Forum), and that, since 2001, have been organized on global, continental, national, and local levels (see e.g. della Porta, 2007). Other scholars have also labeled this movement ‘the alter-globalization movement’ (see e.g. Pleyers, 2010).

The fundamental premise of Peter Wagner’s theory of modernity (1994) is that the cultural self-understanding characterizing modern societies rests on the condition that, during this period, human beings begin to consider themselves as agents of their own destiny, and as beings equipped with capacities to rationally cope with such a condition. During modernity, the foremost principle characterizing society is that of the right of collectivities and individuals to govern themselves, that is, to freely and together with others establish and elaborate different forms of autonomy, or self-government. If autonomy means the freedom to create new rules for society, however, it also often carries restrictions to freedom (since rule-making in itself implies the creation of new boundaries and new forms of mastery). Consequently, Wagner considers the unsolvable tension between liberty and discipline – or between autonomy and rational mastery – as the foundation for the cultural self-understanding of modernity (Wagner, 2001c: 4 ff.). It is out of this tension that new institutions and new forms of knowledge are created and new forms of political decision-making are instituted. As such, modern forms of self-government may be perpetually elaborated and criticized for not sufficiently furthering individual or collective autonomy. If one were to expand Wagner’s conceptual apparatus, it seems reasonable to place social movements among those type of agents that throughout modernity have been active in elaborating forms of autonomy, that is, the self-government of society. When the structural premises for the tension between autonomy and rational mastery have been challenged and renegotiated, resulting in a renewed configuration of modernity, it has often been social movements that played a prominent role (Wennerhag, 2010).

Other influential social theorists have described these transformations in a way reminiscent of Giddens’s account (see e.g. Beck, 1997; Castells, 2000; Fraser, 2005; Inglehart and Welzel, 2005). Nevertheless, we have chosen to mainly focus on Giddens, not only because he is widely referred to in these discussions, but also because his description of the changed relation between individual and collective brings forward the logics of the argument in a very concise manner.

In short, Boltanski and his co-researchers (in particular, Laurent Thévenot) take as their starting point the idea that a plurality of different modes of justification always exist in society. These are understood to be based upon various moral models that mirror different basic normative orientations, but that nevertheless co-exist in the everyday decisions of individuals or social groupings. Normally, these modes of justifications guide everyday actions in a more inarticulate way, and frequently, their differences are neither actively reflected upon nor articulated, except in situations of crisis when disputes occur. In such situations of crisis, the actors have recourse to arguments and reasons concerning why one moral order is preferable to another, particularly when social actions of a set of actors – or in society at large – have to be coordinated (Boltanski and Thévenot, 2006; see also Honneth, 2010).

Especially in Western Europe, the organization Attac has played an important role in mobilizing the Global Justice Movement. Attac was founded in France in 1998, primarily focusing on the introduction of a tax on global financial transactions (the so-called Tobin tax), but later having a broader agenda raising issues about fair trade, third world debt, social welfare, privatizations, and the general regulation of the economy.
